values.alignmentText: In Korea, .NET roles exist mainly in Seoul firms and outsourcing; English-only roles are rare, so Korean skills and some on-site time are common.

South Korea (KR): English is common in many studios, but Korean is often needed; bilingual candidates fit Seoul's game-dev scene.

South Korea's universal healthcare and public wellness programs support families. Parks, schools, and community centers offer preventive care for kids.

Korea normally does not allow dual citizenship; renunciation is usually required; only narrow exceptions apply (rare talent or marriage).

South Korea's solid, export-led economy keeps unemployment low and wages steady, supporting family finances and strong public services for kids.

South Korea provides parental leave and child allowances, but uptake by fathers remains low due to work culture and administrative hurdles.

South Korea: visa families have some access, but many core benefits require residency or employer sponsorship; processes can be opaque.

In Korea, men's fashion is modern in Seoul; urban areas embrace bold trends, while suburbs tend toward classic styles.
South Korea offers autonomy for women, especially in urban areas, but subtle appearance and parenting pressures persist.
In Korea, gun ownership is tightly restricted with strict licensing; civilians rarely encounter firearms, creating a calm, safe environment.

Seoul hosts a healthy founder network with meetups, accelerators, and VC circles; activity is concentrated in the capital.
South Korea's major urban centers offer plentiful produce and diverse cuisines. Some niche ingredients may require a short trip.
South Korea: locals are polite; connect proactively. Seoul/Busan expat networks aid integration, but deeper ties require time and careful community choice.

South Korea has legal gender equality, yet pay gaps and glass ceilings persist; urban centers show progress, rural areas lag.
In South Korea's urban centers, gender roles are increasingly egalitarian, but traditional norms still surface at work and home.
In South Korea, dating culture can be traditional; Seoul has LGBTQ+-friendly spaces, but nontraditional flirting may still draw stares.
South Korea requires pension contributions and routine document checks for visa holders; services are reliable, but visas hinge on employer renewals.
Busan, Korea faces warming, stronger typhoons, and rising seas. Plan housing reinforcement and targeted insurance to mitigate risk.
South Korea offers a startup visa (D-8) with founder-friendly aims, but quotas and documentation can slow timing for families.

South Korea's immigrant sentiment is mixed; public spaces can feel cautious for newcomers, but Seoul offers expat networks and language support.

South Korea experiences rare mass violence. Stay aware at large events in Seoul and nationwide; overall safety remains strong.

Seoul and major Korean cities offer easy transit to mountains, rivers, and parks; many family-friendly trails within short trips.

Seoul has strong nightlife, but family-friendly late options are limited; plan daytime outings and trusted sitters for evenings.

Seoul hosts Nexon, NCSoft, Smilegate, and Krafton with active hiring/events; a strong game-dev ecosystem for networking and growth.
South Korea has low obesity rates thanks to walkable cities, transit, and a healthy diet; aligning with our family health goals.

KR pace varies; Seoul moves fast, but Busan and coastal towns offer milder tempo, helping family downtime and routines.
South Korea's schooling culture prioritizes top academics and active parental involvement. Dual caregiving is common, with some traditional norms.

In South Korea, crowded urban life means closer contact at times; locals typically respect personal space with polite cues.
South Korea offers about six months of pleasant spring and autumn. Summers are hot and humid; winters are cold, so outdoor plans need timing.
South Korea's democracy is stable with competitive elections and independent courts; reforms advance through open civic channels despite polarization.
In Korea, polyamorous families encounter social stigma and laws favor monogamy; parental rights can be uncertain.
Seoul, Korea has childcare options, but waitlists are lengthy and aftercare hours can be inflexible; bilingual preschool access varies.
In South Korea, private options exist but are costly; hagwons are common. Your focus on strong public schools with bilingual exposure fits well.
South Korea has abundant processed snacks and convenience foods. Yet fresh markets and home-style meals support healthier choices for the family.
Seoul's PMM (Games) pay is solid but ~10-15% below top hubs. English-friendly services and strong benefits, plus a reasonable cost of living, help a family settle in.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: Seoul's game scene runs regular PMM trainings. Studios and universities host workshops, with both in-person and online options.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: South Korea has several reputable game/marketing programs feeding local studios (Seoul/Pangyo), with strong industry ties but PMM-specific pipelines vary.
Seoul's gaming PMM market shows solid demand; expect 4–5 month hiring cycles, with expat pipelines and language alignment helping.
Korean is primary for KR game PMs; English aids in Seoul multinationals, but bilingual candidates perform best.
South Korea: remote options exist case-by-case for games PM roles; expect some in-person collaboration, but hybrid setups can fit family needs.
KR's Seoul-area game PMMs: strong mid- to senior-level pool, multilingual candidates; senior hiring remains competitive.
South Korea's major cities (Seoul, Busan) host progressive communities supporting rights and education, but national politics stay mixed with conservative influence.
KR attitudes vary: urban Seoul can be tolerant, but many areas moralize casual sex. Privacy prudent; reputational risk for women/queer folks.

Remote is allowed case-by-case in established South Korea studios; hybrid work is preferred to support family balance.
Seoul-area startups favor hybrid work; remote is possible but role- and trust-dependent, with junior staff often onsite.

In South Korea, visa holders have limited public pension access; as a founder with non-salaried work, private retirement savings become central.

South Korea has low crime and generally safe public transit; most areas are safe for families, with rare incidents well-managed after dark.
KR has strong public schools, but language and workload can be intense; private/bilingual and international options exist in cities, though costly.
South Korea's coastal waters stay around 24-26°C in summer, ideal for family swims. In fall they cool to 20-23°C, so light rash guards help.
South Korea has four seasons: hot, humid summers and cold, snowy winters; monitor typhoons/monsoon rains and plan for humidity and heating needs.
South Korea's winter daylight is shorter; maintain energy with regular outdoor breaks and occasional light therapy.
KR has hot, humid summers and cold winters; overall mild, but humidity/monsoon limits outdoor time; kids can play outside with gear.
Seoul/Pangyo offer senior tech leaders, but many are tied to chaebols; startups must offer competitive packages to attract top talent in Korea.
Sex attitudes in Korea are mixed. Urban areas like Seoul show progress in sex education, but conservative norms persist nationwide.
South Korea offers universal healthcare and expanding childcare subsidies. However, safety nets are uneven and region-dependent for a two-child, two-adult family.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Seoul metro, KR: 2k sq ft rentals are rare and move fast; expect premium rents and broker connections.

South Korea's liberal democracy supports pluralism and civil liberties; security stance against North Korea coexists with vibrant public debate.
South Korea's market blends chaebols with a growing startup scene. Strong safety nets and universal healthcare align with your family's needs.

South Korea shows mixed corruption in corporate ties and procurement, but robust oversight limits impact; for families relocating, routines stay reliable.

In KR, VFX real-time remote options exist but require on-site collaboration. Partial remote weeks are common; fully remote requires negotiation.
South Korea has a solid real-time VFX pool with Seoul studios; mid-to-senior talent exists, but top roles may need relocation or strong local sourcing.
South Korea's neighbors are mixed. Historical tensions with Japan and North Korea persist; China remains pragmatic.
South Korea's confident, export-led identity shines in tech and culture. Yet security concerns and social changes temper the pride.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: In South Korea, neighbors view its strong economy and tech leadership with respect. Security tensions with North Korea and disputes with Japan temper some opinions about the country.
South Korea offers D-8 startup and F-2 routes for US founders, but require language proficiency and proof of funds; competitive but viable with prep.
South Korea's cities offer walkable pockets with sidewalks and transit; plan routes to avoid busy arterials near schools with kids.
In South Korea, US migrants are generally welcomed; urban expat communities aid integration, though learning Korean helps social ties.
South Korea's blend of hi-tech cities, K-pop, and ancient palaces invites frequent family adventures, with easy day trips and early bilingual exposure.
Winter lows near -7°C (19°F) in Seoul; regular freezes with light snow, but milder than Kansas City winters.
South Korea has a 52-hour cap; 45-50 hour weeks are common in startups. Prioritize flex hours to protect family evenings.
South Korea has a 52-hour workweek cap, but overtime and late calls persist in tech; with planning, family time can be protected.
South Korea has broad labor protections and a 52-hour cap. However, gig-work protections lag, which matters for Trey's startup and Sarah's remote work.
